comments.commentBody:
Thank you to a REAL PRESIDENT AND LEADER.
Now, media DO YOUR JOB.
You know longer are invited to White House press briefings where you will hear nothing new about nothing important anyway.
So go, go be a REAL FREE PRESS.
Go and dig up the intel, follow the money and shine a bright light on the TRUTH.
Let's have another Washington Post/ Watergate/ Nixon episode.
Surely this White House fears that.

Time for a Special Prosecutor. Time to look into the Russian file, the conflict of interests and Trump's tax returns. All of these may be related. Now we foreigners can see if all that talk of "checks and balances" means something or is the usual American self-congratulatory hot-air.

replies.commentBody: To say what Comey did was an "error" assumes he did not do it purposely.  What evidence do you have this is so?

Was it a "grave error" for Obama NOT to tell us why he gave 221 MILLION to the Palestinians on his last day in office?    Was it a "grave error" for Obama NOT to explain why he put his mother-in-law on a Federal Retirement scheme?   There is enough stuff that smells to go around.   Be careful what you wish for!
The Russian ties haven't showed-up on any computers yet. That's a large part of this conundrum - there is no proof of any malfeasance.

comments.commentBody:
The Russian-Trump campaign knot is getting tighter and tighter. Trump needs to do some major housecleaning now.

It was a grave error for Pres. Obama not to disclose more to the American people before the election. And it was a grave error for Comey to disclose the Weiner computer but not anything about these Russian ties.

“I have been called a surrogate at a time or two in that campaign and I didn’t have — did not have communications with the Russians, and I’m unable to comment on it,” Mr. Sessions said at the time. Spicer added, “There continues to be no there, there.”

What did Nixon officials say during Watergate?

People of integrity generally want the truth to emerge.  Those who have something to hide, and everything to lose, make up their own facts and layer upon layer of indirection and obfuscation.  Trump has shown a consistent pattern of never backing off a challenge, never admitting a lie, and usually doubling down on it.  This guy has everything to lose, and if things get closer to the truth, he will become more dangerous.

replies.commentBody:
Lying under oath when you are testifying for the role of Attorney General is a Huge, HUGE deal!

If we can't trust the chief law enforcement person, it's not a tiny problem.

comments.commentBody:
Just some quick comments:

1.) Sessions' lying under oath probably does not rise to the standard of perjury -- prosecutors would need to prove that he knew his statement to be false at the time when he made it. Nonetheless, lying under oath is never a good look.

2.) Sessions' meetings with the Russian ambassador may very well have been harmless, but since he's already told one falsehood (whether intentionally or not) about them, he really needs to come absolutely clean now -- e.g. produce whatever records he has of these meetings, no matter what these may be or how embarrassing they may be in some regard. For if he gets caught in another falsehood, it will really start to stink.

3.) The report just mentions contacts between Trump's "associates" and Russian officials. That is certainly smoke, but before we start talking impeachment we need to see some actual fire.

4.) I would feel a lot better if people in this administration started making an effort to tell the truth and to get their facts straight. Facts are stubborn things, and they matter: Spicer should have told his boss that he wasn't going to lie about the crowd's size; Conway should have checked about Bowling Green before she opened her mouth; Sessions should have checked his engagements diary before claiming that he hadn't had meetings with Russian officials; Flynn should have fronted up immediately about what he told the Russian ambassador, and on and on.

replies.commentBody: Richard Nixon?  OK.  But Bill Clinton?  Bill's problem was that one too many people really liked him.  Trump will never have that problem.  The only person that likes Trump is Trump.

comments.commentBody:
Again, w see Democrats crying foul over hacked e-mails. And, how they chose to address it. In addition, completely ignoring the contents. On top of that, they tried to cover up the contents and blame everything on the Trump campaign and Russia. Finally, their candidate continued to lie about her e-mail private server and national security implications.

If the Trump campaign, asked for help from the Russians, and he was aware of it, than that is a criminal act. He, and those involved, should be investigated and prosecuted. As should members of the DNC, as well as Hillary Clinton, and State Department IT staff, for tampering and removal of evidence.

It cut both ways. Out politicians, and political parties, are corrupt. And out of this much, Trump won. The Democrats paid big, because voters did pay attention.

In the end, I do expect President Trump will have similar issues to that of Richard Nixon and Bill Clinton. Scandal will be the order of the day, for the foreseeable future.

It appears to me that Trump cabinet appointees (including but not limited to Sessions) may have already committed criminal and thereby impeachable offenses by failing to uphold their oaths of office. It is "protect and defend the Constitution...against all enemies foreign and domestic" not "Protect my boss and his creditors..."
This whole thing stinks to high heaven and no amount of lipstick on the pig is going to make it beautiful.
Speak out, America!

replies.commentBody:
Really? Reverse the party scenario. If these allegations had surfaced in a Hillary administration, heads would have exploded and multiple multi-million dollar investigations would already be underway.

Denying the seriousness of the danger Russia poses is called cognitive dissonance. A syndrome well entrenched in the Repubs. Those who seek to downplay or bury the intel, have no credibility. Zero. Respect left the building long ago.

Spicer is a shill.

comments.commentBody:
Spicer is right:

“The only new piece of information that has come to light is that political appointees in the Obama administration have sought to create a false narrative to make an excuse for their own defeat in the election.”

This whole Russia "narrative" is Duke Lacrosse on steroids.

If there is a "there" there, as Spicer says, it will come down to the question of whether Trump supporters in the American public,and in our government, dislike American Democrats ( and especially H. Clinton) so intensely that they are willing to excuse Trump and his surrogates working with a communist country (led by a murderous dictator) to interfere in our electoral process. Has it really come to that?
At this point, one has to ask, do Republicans have any sense of decency, or at the very least, embarrassment?
Jeff Sessions LIED WHILE UNDER OATH, clearly demonstrating he has no respect for the RULE OF LAW.  Republicans are actually claiming there's a dispute here?  Good grief.

replies.commentBody: This is not about election results.  Sessions clearly lied under oath during a hearing to be Attorney General.  He is therefore unfit to serve as the country's highest ranking law enforcement officer.  Next.
You wouldn't know real news if it bit you on the nose

Shivers64 represents a segment of he population that has consumed so much of Trumps Cool-Aid that they are completely devoid of objective thought.  Trump could shoot the Pope in the middle Madison Ave and these lemmings would still line up to support him. Truly pathetic. This is a snake oil salesman, who has effectively bilked a large portion of the nation has already caused severe damage to the nation.  I only hope there will be consequences for those who have consumed his toxic "elixir". Perhaps they will all die and the country can move forward without dragging them along.

comments.commentBody: What a very sad pathetic effort to smear our president with FAKE NEWS.  This entire article is just the NYT wishing... nothing happened... and what it's so breathless about that didn't happen isn't even criminal if it did.  So Russians "hacked" the election huh...was a single vote maninupulated or changed and is there even that charge... NO... a private email of a nefarious guy... Podesta was revealed by someone and leaked... rather like what the NYT did with financial documents illegally obtained about Trump.  So I guess the NYT hacked the election too.  YOU LOST.... get over it

This is mind boggling.  There's an odor of treason here.  Putin is a cold blooded killer of his adversaries without morality or compunction.  Just check those families from the Netherlands who happen to be flying over the Ukraine.  The West must be as vigilant as possible with this fellow.  Republicans are beginning to appear as though they've sold their souls for their power.
Thank YOU, president Obama, you are a TRUE Patriot...!!!

replies.commentBody: Silverbaloon, it takes critical thinking to come up with your analysis, which is correct.  Seems the MSM is hoping not too many of its readers/listeners will do the critical thinking necessary to question their agenda.  Thanks for posting.

No one is claiming the Russians hacked voting machines.  The claim is they were behind the DNC leaks and worked to sway public opinion.  Which is plausible and needs investigating.  Beyond that, if the people with the Trump campaign had anything to do with encouraging it or were in contact with those who could, then Trump is president through "ill gotten gains".  That's not the kind of people you want going into a presidency, as we learned with Nixon.

comments.commentBody: Dumb bunny Dems. They have all their eggs in the Russian basket and they tripped and broke all of them. If Russia had done anything HilLIARy would not of won the popular vote. With California using voting machines, why was the margin of her winning so big. Why hack 35 voting systems when they only needed to hack one. Think about it. Russia is FAKE NEWS.  You LOST DEMORATS GET OVER IT.  AMERICA HATES SORE LOSERS AND THAT IS WHAT YOU ARE! 2 year olds pitching a fit because daddy won't buy that toy.  Look a Democrat selfies
What's going on?  Tax returns are the key to Trump's past and our countries future.  Tax returns will restore the rule of law and this shambles of a democracy.

If Sessions lied during his confirmation he should be fired, or better sent to jail. What if any one of us were to do the same. It's not even necessary to prove his nefarious interactions with Russia. CONGRESS GET RID OF HIM OR WE MAKE THE BAR EVEN LOWER.

Let's see:  Looks like Jeff Sessions lies, we already know Donald Trump lies, Kellyanne Conway lies, Sean Spicer lies, Stephen Miller can't seem to tell the truth. Can we trust what anyone in this administration tells us?

replies.commentBody: American intelligence won't give specific names and sources except to an independent prosecutor

comments.commentBody:
Here is my take on this. First off nobody on the left thought Trump would win. Trump was worried about fraud and hacking and Obama told us all straight faced that there was no fear of Russia Hacking the elections. Then all of a sudden Trump wins by going to the right states like many before him and takes the electoral college from Hillary and Wins the presidency. Now Obama's entire legacy is in danger because the new president elect has a totally different vision for America. Which gives Obama motive to lay a seed like this unproven Russian hacking theory that will hover over the new presidents presidency and make it harder for him to do the work he was elected to do.

The Russians hacked the DNC through Podestas emails and his password was "password" ? Come on people 4 Chan hackers claimed responsibility hours after the official wiki leaks release of these emails. This was not a hack because a hack imply's breaching security in which there was none.

There is about as much credibility to these claims as the one we are getting from the media right now. No facts, just hearsay from both liberal and conservatives. Until I see actual facts with provable NAMES no SOURCES. I will not for a minute believe these stories.

Jeff, how could you? To that Jeff answers, ''Ah, get over it. You will have to believe my words, if say what I didn't. Or if didn't say what said. Moreover, I didn't say it. I couldn't say it. Even if did, I couldn't say I said it. See what I'm saying?'' Meanwhile, the listener's head is spinning outta control, and he or she gets almost a classical migraine.

Again, it is highly enticing for anyone to that say a few of Trump's staff seem to revel in dissembling, especially when it comes to defending their derrieres, if Putin is in the picture. Whether there was Russian influence in altering the 2016 election results or not, remains to be proven, beyond any reasonable doubts. In addition, Sean Spicer castigates those trouble makers, and apparently implies that all these are unfounded theories, and had no bearing on the 2016 elections.

Anyone who relies on Spicer's innuendos, needs a head-shrink. Maybe. News media are delving quite a bit deeper onto these smoking hot issues, and will, believably, exhume the truth as it existed. And if the truth hurts, many GOP heads might roll.
Where there's smoke, there's fire. So Mr. Spicer, if it looks like something is wrong, something probably is wrong.

replies.commentBody:
I was and continue to be a Sanders supporter .You have a valid point here.
The media continues to quote these no name persons .It is getting to the point where it may all be contrived .No, not all of us are gullible .

On 3/2, JD Gordon stated that Mr Trump had explicitly requested that the RNC platform, which is intended to define policy for the Republican Candidate, should be changed.

He did so to his advisers in March of 2016, months ahead of the convention.

He wanted to remove the language in the platform that expressed support for the Ukrainian government by committing to supplying them weapons.

Mr Trump is notoriously ignorant regarding US foreign policy, and our positions with respect to the Ukraine and Russia. That he would make this request the way he did, when he did, and as specifically as he did, suggests that it was not originally his idea.

This is a textbook case of a smoking gun.

It is wrong to believe that because a story hasn't been blown completely out into the open that there isn't a story there. Oftentimes it takes constant pushing by the public, the press and elected officials to have the truth come out. And if there was nothing to these allegations, Sessions would not have lied during his confirmation hearing about his meetings with the Russian ambassador. As the age-old adage states, "where there is smoke, there is fire."

comments.commentBody: Why so much anonymity?  Where are the names, the dates, the locations, who are the "officials"?  When you have nothing of substance to attach to your accusations they remain just accusations.  The only reason accusations are tossed around like that is to create suspicion or to fabricate a scenario...or a story that will sell.  The left's reaction to Trump's election and his presidency and their digging to undermine it, is itself a story, a story that eventually will come undone.  It's like the kid who tells an untruth or half truth to cover an earlier untruth, sooner or later nobody is buying it.  The accusations will be followed with, "How do you know this"?

Dear NYT,

DO YOUR JOB. DON'T QUIT INVESTIGATING. The press and the judicial system may be all we have left of this so-called democracy.

Sincerely,

Lon L. Peters
Pasadena, California

replies.commentBody: He won the white working class vote.  Who's your 'common people'?

comments.commentBody:
Mr. Spicer says “The only new piece of information that has come to light is that political appointees in the Obama administration have sought to create a false narrative to make an excuse for their own defeat in the election.”

Mr. Spicer again ignores the fact that Mr. Trump LOST the popular vote. I concede that Trump won among the elite -- the electoral college -- but we must never lose sight of the fact that he lost among us common people.
